reviewText: "The Haunted Boy: The Secret Diary of the Exorcist" is certainly an entertaining ride put together by uber parapsychologists/demonologists "The Booth Brothers".I think at this point everyone who is interested in the story knows a little bit about the story.  William Peter Blatty was a student of the exceptional Jesuit Father William Bowdern.  Father Bowdern at some point gave Blatty the diary of an exorcism performed by Bowdern and a company of fellow priests.  Somehow (supposedly) the real diary mysteriously fell into the hands of the Booth Brothers (or they made a juicy financial deal with the author of the "Exorcist" and got half the diary-- both parties coming away pleased with the marked increase in their checkbooks).Here we are treated to a host of people who were actually involved with the exorcism, the most compass menace of which is Bowdern's great niece Eileen Dreyer.  Two of the Jesuits who were actually present--Father Francis X. Clearly and Father W. Faherty--are wheelchair bound and barely cognizant.  Though still retaining his sense of humor and obviously having the fighting spirit of St. Ignatius, things get a bit muddled when Father Clearly first denies knowing anything about the case.  Then, he insists that the exorcism was absolutely authentic and that the boy's bed would levitate.  Later on, in the Special Features, he's just not sure any of it was true at all and speculates that the boy's aunt, who was involved in ouija boards, all kindsa weird stuff, may have molested the kid.  Or someone else may have--extrapolate on that one.  (He also drools a lot.)  Did it ever occur to the Booth Brothers that putting this man on camera might be a bit beneath his dignity at this point in his life?Bishop Long, a diocesan exorcist, was the one who impressed me the most.  He states unequivocally that a lot of the fundies running around trying to exorcize people, and the constant interest in demons and the rest of it may just not be a good thing.  This needed to be said: unless you have actual qualifications and are not just taking some pet interest in a phenomena which is to be taken seriously indeed if one believes, perhaps you should stay out of the very hot kitchen.The re-enactments of the exorcism are fantastic and perhaps the best part of the film--some parts are genuinely frightening.  Not being a huge believer in things like Electronic Voice Phenomenon and the rest of it, I have to say that it was a bit embarrassing to watch some of the Booth Brother's crew run into the sealed off room in which the boy was exorcized and expect us to take all of the ghost hunting stuff seriously.  An EVP scan is run on the room and the demon is asked to identify itself: the message received is "My name is Legion."  Just too perfect for me. Perhaps what made me the most incredulous was the psychic, Vicki, who was standing there with a pair of divining rods and telling all of us, word for word, that St. Michael the Archangel was invisibly doing battle with the entity that was in the room. The "audio Exorcism archives" are taken from the audio footage of Anneliese Michel, the German girl upon whom the filmThe Exorcism of Emily Rose - Unrated (Special Edition)was based.All said and done, I'd just to like to hear something from the horse's mouth--Roland or Robbie or whatever his name is.  If it was an act or the behavior of a rebellious teenager, perhaps he should speak up and settle the whole thing once and for all, though he has the perfect right not to.  And if it was something else, something not supernatural at all but traumatic, he should DEFINITELY speak up.  The danger with all this fascination is that his identity could actually be revealed one day.All in all, an entertaining romp through the graveyard.  I myself am a Roman Catholic and do not deny the possibility of demonic possession: what I'm not so sure about, though, is whether we should have every crank in the world running to and fro and obsessing over every detail of it. (The Booth Brothers could make fantastic films--I've never seen such a creepy looking little possessed boy, and they've made quite a few terrible movies about this case.)

reviewText: I love occult documentaries and this one started off wonderfully they went over facts, discussed events, what happened, and the re enactments were nice and added to it, I was really into it, Like the people to, it's scary as hell..BUT then here comes the lady with the Dowsing rod with crystals on it WT?, my mom grew up on a farm and knows well how it's doneRecipe For DisasterCombine a few PSYCHICS, 1 woman with a DOWSING ROD,  2 BROTHERS with cameras, add a cup of SHOWBOATING, and some PARANORMAL INVESTIGATOR wanna be's, with a dash of WHAT THE HELL WERE THEY THINKING mix throughly and ta da you have this  lovely 3 ring circus. This started out as a great documentary that sadly and swiftly turned into a 3 ring circus, don't waste your money like I just did
summary: Starts Off Well-Then Showboating Makes A Recipe For Dsaster

reviewText: Not bad - but there is some better on the issue out there.  Like most of the creators DVD's, I struggle with the over dramatic "ballyhoo" showmanship effects they tend to employee - overpowers actual investigative information.  I really suggest a rental first or, see of there is a cheaper download to self-burn the DVD if you have that ablility.  They get points for heavy dramatics and DVD graphics effects - but it tends to come off like a "Haunted House" effect - playing for flash and scares versus focus on the topic -- and the pizza guy? (special features)

reviewText: In The Haunted Boy paranormal "dream-team" filmmakers Christopher Saint Booth and Philip Adrian Booth investigate the real-life events that inspired author William Peter Blatty's book and the wildly-popular film, "The Exorcist" and take us on a journey into a reality that is frightening yet ultimately inspiring.The Booth Brothers can also be commended for not missing an opportunity to educate the general public about the dangers of the paranormal; the film includes footage of the brothers speaking to a classroom filled with students approximately the same age as the possessed boy when he began experimenting with the Ouija board, the singular object believed responsible for bringing about the harrowing circumstances of the Haunted Boy's demonic possession and torment. The Booth Brothers also provide further evidence of the dangers of Quija through interviews with individuals who have experienced psychic and physical attacks - even contact with infamous serial killers! - through ignorant experimentation with the board.The film culminates in a visit to the actual, real-life childhood home of the possessed boy - the place where it all began - and the "pay-off" is a big one! With the help of professionals such as Greg Myers and Sandra Oates of Missouri's Paranormal Task Force, and medium Vicki Main, R.N. drawing on the help of St. Michael the Archangel, the Booths confront the demonic entities still lurking at the location. Several graphic scenes - including a demonic attack on expert Greg Myers - prove that the Booth Brothers have no fear of "pushing the envelope" when it comes to confronting true evil face-to-face.Input from individuals such as Father Francis X. Cleary, S.J., and Father W. Faherty, S.J., witnesses to the actual 1949 exorcism, and Thomas Sachy, M.D., a Forensic Criminal Psychiatrist who specializes in the study of genuine possession, and poignant remembrances by relatives such as Eileen Dreyer, the great-niece of Fr. William Bowdern, the man who - in faith alone - faced down the Devil himself, help to round out this thrilling exploration of one of the most enduring and disturbing events in paranormal history.One viewing of The Haunted Boy should leave no doubt in anyone's mind that possession by demons is a very real danger to humankind. To their credit, however, the Booth Brothers choose not to allow the darkness of the subject to be all that we take away from the record of their experiences. In the end, The Haunted Boy, for all its oppressive subject-matter and disturbing evidence of the reality of hell, successfully reaffirms in the viewer a faith in the goodness of mankind, and an admiration for the faith and courage those who deal directly with the supernatural must draw on every day.With moody music created especially for the film by Christopher Saint Booth, paranormal evidence such as real-time EVPs and camera-captures, and disturbing archival, architectural, and expert evidence, the Booth Brothers' The Haunted Boy is a do-not-miss for Halloween and a must-own for paranormal experts and fans alike. Bravo! Highest Rated DVD to date ~ 5 skulls " A Must See!" " Do not miss this one." Monica Garske
